title: Build WebSocket control server
description:
Create server/control.py — asyncio WebSocket server for robot control.

PROTOCOL: see docs/protocol.md
- Client sends: {type:'drive', axis_x, axis_y} at ~20Hz, {type:'mode', mode}, {type:'ping'}
- Server sends: {type:'state', mode, connected} at ~5Hz, {type:'pong'}, {type:'error', message}

IMPLEMENTATION:
- Use 'websockets' library (installed in .venv), asyncio event loop
- Listen on port 8765, accept ONE client (reject additional with error message)
- On 'drive' message: call motors.arcade_mix(axis_x, axis_y) then motors.set_motors(left, right)
- On 'mode' message: call sirens.play_siren(mode)
- Dead-man's switch: track last_message_time. asyncio task checks every 100ms, calls motors.stop() if >500ms stale. See robothector-2wg.3 for full spec.
- On client disconnect: motors.stop(), sirens.stop_sirens()
- Send state message every 200ms (5Hz)

EXISTING CODE TO USE:
- server/motors.py — arcade_mix(axis_x, axis_y), set_motors(left, right), stop(), init(), cleanup()
- server/sirens.py — play_siren(mode), stop_sirens(), init(), cleanup()

Run: uv run python -c 'from server.control import ControlServer; ...' (or via server/main.py)
close_reason: Built server/control.py: WebSocket server with drive/mode/ping dispatch, single-client, 5Hz state broadcast.

IMPLEMENTATION:

  - GET /health — returns 200 OK with JSON {status:'ok', resolution:[w,h]}

CAMERA VERIFIED: ssh robothector 'libcamera-hello --list-cameras' shows IMX708. Picamera2 API tested and working (see closed task robothector-cv2.2).

title: Implement dead-man's switch safety mechanism
description:
Implement dead-man's switch in server/control.py (part of the WebSocket server, task robothector-2wg.1).

SPEC (from docs/protocol.md):
- Track last_message_time = time.monotonic() on every received message
- Watchdog asyncio task runs every 100ms:
  - If now - last_message_time > 0.5s: call motors.stop(), log warning
  - If now - last_message_time > 5.0s: log 'SAFE MODE', set a safe_mode flag
- On client disconnect (WebSocket close): immediately call motors.stop() and sirens.stop_sirens()
- On server startup: motors start stopped (motors.init() already does this)
- On server shutdown (SIGTERM): motors.stop(), motors.cleanup()

CRITICAL: This must be implemented BEFORE any real driving tests. motors.stop() must NEVER raise — wrap in try/except.

This task is logically part of robothector-2wg.1 (control server) but called out separately for safety visibility.
close_reason: Dead-man's switch implemented in control.py: 500ms motor stop, 5s safe mode, disconnect cleanup.

title: Build client WebSocket sender/receiver
description:
Create client/network.py — WebSocket client that sends commands and receives state.

PROTOCOL: see docs/protocol.md

INTERFACE:
  class NetworkClient:
    __init__(host='robothector.local', ws_port=8765)
    start() — spawn background thread, connect WebSocket
    stop() — close connection, join thread
    send_drive(axis_x, axis_y) — queue a drive message
    send_mode(mode) — queue a mode message
    get_state() -> dict or None — latest state from server
    is_connected() -> bool

IMPLEMENTATION:
- Background thread runs a send/receive loop
- Send queue (thread-safe collections.deque or queue.Queue): main loop pushes, bg thread pops and sends
- Receive: parse JSON state messages, store latest in a thread-safe variable
- Auto-reconnect: on disconnect, retry every 2s, log attempts
- Discovery fallback: if WebSocket connect fails, try client.discovery.discover() to find IP

DEPS: websocket-client (installed in .venv). Use websocket.WebSocket (synchronous API) in the bg thread — simpler than async for a threaded pygame app.
close_reason: Built client/network.py: threaded WebSocket client with auto-reconnect and discovery fallback.

title: Build client MJPEG video display
description:
Create client/video.py — MJPEG stream receiver and pygame surface decoder.

INTERFACE:
  class VideoStream:
    __init__(host='robothector.local', video_port=5000)
    start() — spawn background thread, connect to MJPEG stream
    stop() — close connection, join thread
    get_frame() -> pygame.Surface or None — latest decoded frame
    is_connected() -> bool

IMPLEMENTATION:
- Background thread connects to http://<host>:<port>/video_feed
- Use urllib.request.urlopen with stream, read multipart/x-mixed-replace boundaries
- Parse boundary: read until '--frame\r\n', then Content-Type header, then JPEG bytes until next boundary
- Decode JPEG to pygame.Surface: write bytes to io.BytesIO, then pygame.image.load(bio, 'frame.jpg')
- Store latest surface in a thread-safe variable (threading.Lock around surface reference swap)
- On connection loss: set is_connected=False, retry every 2s
- If no frame yet or disconnected: get_frame() returns None (caller shows 'No Signal' placeholder)

TARGET: 640x480 JPEG frames at 15-30 FPS. Decoding should be <10ms per frame on desktop.
close_reason: Built client/video.py: MJPEG stream reader with JPEG marker parsing into pygame Surfaces.

title: Build client main loop and HUD
description:

DISPLAY: 1280x800 (Steam Deck native, also works on desktop). Fullscreen by default, F11 to toggle.

  1. joystick.get_input() -> axis_x, axis_y, mode
  2. network.send_drive(axis_x, axis_y) + send_mode(mode) if changed

  - If no frame: dark grey background with 'No Signal' text
  - Top-left overlay: connection status (green dot = connected, red = disconnected), latency
  - Top-right: current mode ('FIREFIGHTER' in red, 'AMBULANCE' in blue, or nothing)
  - Bottom-center: mini joystick indicator (small circle showing stick position)

COMPONENTS TO IMPORT:

Add client/__main__.py for 'uv run python -m client.main' support.

title: Create systemd service for Pi server
description:
Create robothector.service systemd unit file and install script.

UNIT FILE (robothector.service):
  [Unit]
  Description=Robothector Robot Server
  After=network-online.target
  Wants=network-online.target

  [Service]
  Type=simple
  User=robothector
  WorkingDirectory=/home/robothector/robothector
  ExecStart=/home/robothector/.local/bin/uv run python -m server.main
  Restart=on-failure
  RestartSec=5
  Environment=PYTHONUNBUFFERED=1

  [Install]
  WantedBy=multi-user.target

INSTALL SCRIPT (scripts/install-service.sh):
  sudo cp robothector.service /etc/systemd/system/
  sudo systemctl daemon-reload
  sudo systemctl enable robothector
  sudo systemctl start robothector

NOTE: User is 'robothector' (not root). GPIO access requires the user to be in the 'gpio' group — verify with: ssh robothector 'groups' and 'sudo usermod -aG gpio robothector' if needed. uv is at /home/robothector/.local/bin/uv (installed during Phase 0).

VERIFY: sudo systemctl status robothector shows active. Survives reboot. Client can connect to ws://<ip>:8765 and http://<ip>:5000/video_feed.

title: Phase 4: Bidirectional Audio
description:
Two-way audio between Steam Deck/desktop and robot via I2S audio on Pi.

HARDWARE (ordered):
- Pi mic: INMP441 or ICS43434 I2S MEMS microphone (captures robot environment)
- Pi speaker: MAX98357A I2S 3W amplifier module (plays operator voice)
- Client: desktop/Steam Deck built-in mic + speakers

ARCHITECTURE:
- Pi captures I2S mic → streams PCM over UDP:5001 → client plays through speakers
- Client captures mic → streams PCM over UDP:5002 → Pi plays through MAX98357A
- Push-to-talk first, full duplex later

GPIO CONFLICT: GPIO 19 is used by both motor IN2 and I2S LRCLK. Must rewire IN2 to a free GPIO before adding audio. See pinout.md.

title: Research audio stack on Steam Deck and Pi
description:
Now that hardware is chosen (INMP441/ICS43434 I2S mic + MAX98357A I2S amp), research focuses on:

1. I2S kernel overlay: which dtoverlay for INMP441 + MAX98357A simultaneously? Can both share BCLK/LRCLK?
2. ALSA config: verify capture from I2S mic (arecord) and playback to I2S amp (aplay)
3. Python audio library: sounddevice (uses PortAudio/ALSA) vs pyaudio — which handles I2S devices better?
4. Client side: PyAudio/sounddevice for desktop mic capture + speaker playback
5. Transport: UDP raw PCM (16-bit mono 16kHz = 32KB/s) vs Opus compression
6. Latency budget: target <300ms one-way for usable voice
7. GPIO 19 conflict: IN2 must move to a free pin (e.g. GPIO 12 or 16) before I2S can be enabled

I2S PIN MAPPING (from pinout.md):
  GPIO 18 (pin 12) = PCM_CLK / BCLK (shared)
  GPIO 19 (pin 35) = PCM_FS / LRCLK (shared) ← CONFLICTS with motor IN2
  GPIO 20 (pin 38) = PCM_DIN (mic data)
  GPIO 21 (pin 40) = PCM_DOUT (speaker data)

OUTPUT: docs/audio-design.md with dtoverlay config, wiring diagram, library choice, protocol.

title: Wire I2S audio modules and resolve GPIO 19 conflict
description:
Physical wiring and Pi configuration for INMP441/ICS43434 mic and MAX98357A amp.

STEPS:
1. Rewire motor IN2 from GPIO 19 (pin 35) to a free GPIO (e.g. GPIO 16 pin 36 or GPIO 12 pin 32)
2. Update server/motors.py pin constant: IN2 = <new pin>
3. Update pinout.md with new motor wiring
4. Run server/motor_test.py to verify motors still work after rewire
5. Wire INMP441/ICS43434 I2S mic:
   - VDD → 3.3V (pin 1)
   - GND → GND (pin 6 or 14)
   - SCK → GPIO 18 (pin 12) BCLK
   - WS  → GPIO 19 (pin 35) LRCLK
   - SD  → GPIO 20 (pin 38) DIN
   - L/R → GND (left channel) or VDD (right channel)
6. Wire MAX98357A I2S amp:
   - VIN → 5V (pin 2)
   - GND → GND
   - BCLK → GPIO 18 (pin 12)
   - LRCLK → GPIO 19 (pin 35)
   - DIN → GPIO 21 (pin 40) DOUT
7. Enable I2S overlay: add dtoverlay line to /boot/config.txt (per research task)
8. Reboot Pi, verify with: arecord -l and aplay -l showing I2S devices
9. Test mic: arecord -D hw:X,0 -f S16_LE -r 16000 -c 1 test.wav (5s)
10. Test speaker: aplay -D hw:Y,0 test.wav

DEPENDS ON: robothector-cvu.1 (research determines exact dtoverlay and wiring)

title: Implement UDP beacon discovery fallback
description:
Create server/discovery.py and client/discovery.py for UDP beacon auto-discovery.

SERVER (server/discovery.py):
- Broadcast UDP beacon on port 5555 every 2s on the LAN broadcast address
- JSON payload: {"name": "robothector", "ip": "<local_ip>", "ws_port": 8765, "video_port": 5000}
- Use socket.SO_BROADCAST, send to 255.255.255.255:5555
- Run as a background thread, started from server/main.py

CLIENT (client/discovery.py):
- Listen on UDP port 5555 for beacon packets
- Return first valid beacon as (ip, ws_port, video_port) tuple
- Timeout after 5s if no beacon found
- Used by client/network.py as fallback when robothector.local doesn't resolve

WHY: mDNS is unreliable on Steam Deck (see docs/steamdeck-env.md). This is the primary discovery mechanism.

Deps installed: socket (stdlib), json (stdlib) — no extra packages needed.
